title: HPE OneView CVSS 10.0 RCE: RondoDox Botnet Launches 40,000+ Attack Campaign (CISA KEV)
affected_products: HPE OneView versions 5.20 through 10.20 without hotfix
Data center infrastructure managed by vulnerable HPE OneView instances

timeline.event: CVE-2025-37164 published to NVD, reported by security researcher Nguyen Quoc Khanh
HPE releases security advisory and hotfix for vulnerable OneView versions
Metasploit module for CVE-2025-37164 publicly released
Check Point detects 40,000+ attack attempts between 05:45-09:20 UTC
CISA adds CVE-2025-37164 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
RondoDox botnet attribution confirmed, campaign continues globally

simple_summary.what_happened: A maximum severity vulnerability (CVSS 10.0) in HPE OneView infrastructure management platform is being massively exploited by the RondoDox botnet. Check Point Research detected over 40,000 automated attack attempts in just 3.5 hours on January 7, 2026. The flaw allows unauthenticated remote code execution through an exposed REST API endpoint (/rest/id-pools/executeCommand) that executes attacker input directly on the operating system.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Organizations using HPE OneView versions prior to 11.0 for data center infrastructure management. The campaign has primarily targeted government organizations, financial services, and industrial manufacturing sectors. Geographic focus includes the United States (highest volume), Australia, France, Germany, and Austria. Any organization with internet-exposed OneView instances is at critical risk.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Scan for exposed HPE OneView instances on the internet. Step 2: Send unauthenticated HTTP requests to /rest/id-pools/executeCommand endpoint. Step 3: Inject arbitrary commands that execute directly on the underlying OS. Step 4: Deploy RondoDox botnet malware payload. Step 5: Use compromised infrastructure for DDoS attacks, cryptomining, or secondary payload delivery. Step 6: Potentially pivot to managed infrastructure (servers, firmware, lifecycle management) given OneView's privileged position.
what_you_should_do: Immediately upgrade to HPE OneView 11.0 or apply the security hotfix
Block external access to HPE OneView management interfaces
Check for signs of compromise - unusual processes, network connections, cryptomining
Review firewall rules to block access to /rest/id-pools/executeCommand endpoint
Monitor for connections from known malicious Dutch IP associated with RondoDox
Audit all infrastructure managed by potentially compromised OneView instances
Implement network segmentation to isolate management platforms
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: HPE OneView is a privileged control plane for enterprise data center infrastructure. It manages servers, storage, networking, and firmware lifecycles at scale. Successful exploitation doesn't just mean RCE on one system - it means potential centralized control over the entire managed infrastructure. Management platforms like OneView are typically deployed deep inside networks with extensive privileges and minimal monitoring. The RondoDox botnet's automated exploitation campaign demonstrates opportunistic attackers are already weaponizing this vulnerability at scale, with a public Metasploit module making exploitation trivial.

tactics.description: Exploiting the unauthenticated REST API endpoint in HPE OneView
Executing arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system
RondoDox botnet establishing persistence on compromised systems
Using compromised systems for cryptomining operations
Using compromised systems as part of DDoS botnet infrastructure
Using OneView's management capabilities to pivot to managed infrastructure

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for unauthorized access to HPE OneView REST API endpoints, particularly /rest/id-pools/executeCommand. Look for signs of RondoDox botnet activity including cryptomining processes and unusual outbound connections.

log_sources.description: API access logs showing requests to vulnerable endpoints
Unusual inbound connections to OneView management ports
Cryptomining processes or unusual binary execution

what_to_look_for.description: Connections from known RondoDox-associated Dutch IP address
what_to_look_for.log_field: Source IP in threat intelligence feeds

what_to_look_for.description: High CPU usage processes associated with cryptocurrency mining
what_to_look_for.log_field: Process names like xmrig, minerd, or high CPU usage

what_to_look_for.description: Commands spawned by OneView application processes
what_to_look_for.log_field: Process tree showing OneView spawning shell commands

what_to_look_for.description: Outbound connections to known RondoDox C2 infrastructure

immediate_actions.description: Immediately block internet access to HPE OneView management interfaces
Upgrade to HPE OneView 11.0 or apply security hotfix for versions 5.20-10.20
Review systems for signs of RondoDox malware, cryptomining, or unauthorized access
Review all systems managed by potentially compromised OneView for anomalies
Isolate infrastructure management platforms from general network access
